awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Core Support for Future Earth International Global Change Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports the US Secretariat of Future Earth. Future Earth harnesses the insights and capacity of the global scientific community to address global problems, like a warming and increasingly unstable climate, and a rapid loss of biodiversity and ecosystem services. The Future Earth effort is based on the recognition that modern global change challenges require coordinated research efforts bringing together the world's best researchers in the natural, social, behavioral, and engineering sciences, and connecting these researchers with the needs and capacities embedded within a wide range of stakeholder institutions and communities. The Secretariat leads and co-leads core functions that include research enabling, networks and capacity, information technology, and communications. In addition, the US Global Hub leads the evolution and growth of Future Earth’s global efforts and directs many of Future Earth’s core global initiatives, including a flagship capacity building program, communications products, and collaborative data-platforms.

Future Earth provides a critical service to the science community by advancing global change science in the US and around the world, and by supporting the full range of research modalities from fundamental disciplinary research to transdisciplinary research. By connecting research across geography and discipline, the project supports the emergence of novel, integrative scientific ideas. By elevating the spread and impact of scientific results and connecting these results with constituencies in business, government, and civil society, Future Earth’s work supports decision making around the world. It also connects US researchers with a vast and rapidly growing network of leading international scholars in global change research and provides direct access to new knowledge and initiatives. This work includes a broad range of communication capacities in the US and around the world, like the establishment of the Sustainability Research and Innovation Congress, the first global convening that brings the global change research and innovation communities together, on an annual basis. The Future Earth US Global Hub has also established partnerships to build and diversify the next generation of global change researchers through an internship program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Future Earth is a global network organization advancing transdisciplinary and sustainability science. The US Global Secretariat Hub (US Hub) is one of the nine offices of Future Earth's distributed global Secretariat, and it leads several key functions, ranging from global communications, IT and finance, to the coordination of the national committees and global research networks. In addition, the US Hub leads two rapidly growing international programs: the Sustainability Research and Innovation Congress (SRI) and the Anthropocene Magazine, and coordinates the PEGASuS funding initiative.


This project includes activities in four work areas: 1) Convening and Connecting Communities, 2) Coordinating Research, 3) Collaborating, and 4) Building a More Global Network.


Convening and Connecting Communities:

The SRI Congress, which is a partnership with the Belmont Forum, is rapidly being established as the world's leading sustainability science gathering. This annual event, launched in 2021, has convened over 1500 participants each year from more than 100 countries. The fully hybrid congress and its regional satellite events (in 2023 Africa and Asia) feature 200 sessions showcasing new transdisciplinary and global change research and innovation and offering several training and networking opportunities. Committed to increasing inclusivity in global conferencing, SRI awards several participation scholarships to attendees from low and middle-income countries and applies diversity criteria to organizational processes from session proposal review to program committee member and plenary speaker selection. SRI2022 was held in Pretoria, South Africa, and SRI2023 will be held in Panama City, Panama. The 2023 congress will be fully bilingual (English / Spanish) and will feature an Open Day. The Open Day is organized in collaboration with local institutions and will showcase local sustainability activities while bringing the Congress closer to the Panamanian public. SRI has been featured in local media, both in South Africa and Panama, and a partnership with a Latin American communications company is helping participants publish their work in regional media outlets and reach wider audiences. In addition, an SRI2023 special issue is underway in a peer-reviewed journal. SRI is supported by several partnerships with local companies, government and higher education institutions, and international organizations. In February 2023, SRI concluded a bidding competition for the hosts of SRI2024 and SRI2025, and is now developing a pathway to grow the congress series with the new hosts which will bring the event to new continents and communities.


This grant also enabled the coordination of the 19 Future Earth national committees, which advance sustainability and global change research in their respective countries, and the development of the new Future Earth Member Portal. A global network team has been established to advance the network work, with a stronger regional focus.


Coordinating research:

This grant leveraged significant work and funding in the field of research and innovation, such as the Program for Early-stage Grants Advancing Sustainability Science (PEGASuS), funded by the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation and now in its fifth cycle; and support for the Belmont Forum in Collaborative Research Action development. Moreover, the US Hub provided liaison support for the 27 Future Earth Global Research Networks, increasing the reach and accessibility of the research that is being done by these networks around the world. The US Hub also leads a project to deliver an European Commission independent expert report on gaps in climate and biodiversity science.


Collaborating:

The US Hub actively developed collaborations with the other USGCRP-funded and supported organizations. For example, the Inter-American Institute for Global Change Research joined SRI2022 as a sponsor and will co-host SRI2023, together with the National Secretariat of Science, Technology and Innovation of Panama. SRI, which is a collaboration with the Belmont Forum, has been a fertile platform for developing new collaborations, which are sought both with domestic and international organizations.


Building a More Global Network:

The US Hub played a leading role in managing the expansion of the Future Earth global secretariat to include three new offices in Asia and one in Africa, dramatically expanding the reach and impact of Future Earth in regions traditionally less-well connected to international global change research. In addition, the Hub continued to lead Future Earth's global coordination work, from managing global finances to coordinating the Governing Council, Assembly and Directors Council meetings. The Hub also manages global IT, finances and communications.
